skill.name: citation-management
skill.description: Comprehensive citation management for academic research. Search Google Scholar and PubMed for papers, extract accurate metadata, validate citations, and generate properly formatted BibTeX entries. This skill should be used when you need to find papers, verify citation information, convert DOIs to BibTeX, or ensure reference accuracy in scientific writing.
skill.summary: Comprehensive citation management for academic research. Search Google Scholar and PubMed for papers...
skill.author: davila7

security_audit.summary: Legitimate citation management toolkit with standard file I/O and API calls to recognized academic services (CrossRef, PubMed, arXiv). All scripts are clearly documented Python code with no malicious patterns, obfuscation, or suspicious capabilities. Network calls are limited to scholarly APIs with rate limiting. Optional API keys for NCBI services are accessed via environment variables only when provided by the user.

content.value_statement: Researchers spend hours manually formatting citations and checking reference accuracy. This skill automates searches across academic databases, extracts metadata from DOIs and other identifiers, validates citation information, and generates properly formatted BibTeX entries for error-free bibliographies.
actual_capabilities: Search Google Scholar and PubMed for academic papers with filters for year, publication type, and keywords
Extract metadata from DOIs, PMIDs, arXiv IDs, and URLs using CrossRef, PubMed, and arXiv APIs
Validate citation accuracy including DOI verification, required field checking, and duplicate detection
Format and clean BibTeX files with standardization, sorting, and deduplication
Convert DOIs directly to properly formatted BibTeX entries
Generate validation reports and fix common citation errors automatically
limitations: Requires internet connection for API queries to scholarly databases
Google Scholar searches use the scholarly library which may be rate-limited
Cannot access subscription-only content behind paywalls
Manual verification recommended for most critical citations before submission
Does not support citation styles other than BibTeX format

use_cases.title: Build thesis bibliographies
use_cases.description: Search multiple databases systematically, extract metadata for all references, and generate clean BibTeX files ready for LaTeX thesis documents.

use_cases.title: Prepare journal submissions
use_cases.description: Validate existing citation collections for accuracy, verify DOIs resolve correctly, and ensure references meet journal formatting requirements.

use_cases.title: Manage ongoing projects
use_cases.description: Track citations across research projects with automated extraction from DOIs and PMIDs, maintaining consistent formatting throughout.

output: Found article in Nature (2024) with 3 authors
DOI resolves correctly to publisher site
Generated BibTeX entry with all required fields

best_practices: Always validate citations before manuscript submission using the validation scripts
Use DOIs as the primary identifier for modern publications (post-2000)
Run deduplication after combining citations from multiple sources
Verify critical citations manually against the original publication
anti_patterns: Manually typing BibTeX entries instead of using metadata extraction
Ignoring DOI validation errors without investigation
Mixing citation key formats within the same bibliography
Submitting without running the validation script

faq.question: Which databases can this skill search?
faq.answer: Google Scholar and PubMed are supported. Google Scholar provides broad coverage across all disciplines while PubMed specializes in biomedical literature with MeSH term support.

faq.question: What citation formats are supported?
faq.answer: Only BibTeX format is supported for export. This works with LaTeX documents and can be converted to other formats using external tools if needed.

faq.question: How does it handle API rate limits?
faq.answer: Scripts implement automatic rate limiting with delays between requests. PubMed allows 3 requests per second without an API key and 10 per second with one. Google Scholar uses longer delays to avoid blocking.

faq.question: Is my citation data stored or transmitted anywhere?
faq.answer: No. All processing happens locally. Network calls only go to official academic APIs (CrossRef, PubMed, arXiv) to retrieve public metadata. No user data is collected or transmitted.

faq.question: Why are some DOIs failing validation?
faq.answer: Common causes include typos in the DOI, the paper being retracted, the DOI belonging to an older publication without digital registration, or the publisher having changed the identifier. Always verify against the original source.

faq.question: How does this compare to reference managers like Zotero?
faq.answer: This skill provides programmatic access for automation and integration into workflows. For interactive browsing and manual management, desktop reference managers offer more features. Use this skill for batch operations and validation.
